Hi,
	I read this paper with some interest.  As you may have gathered from my 
other posts, I'm interesting in anything that combines evolving components 
into modular frameworks.

	I'm a bit puzzled about how the networks placed stones.  If the game 
consisted of placing 5 stones, was the network reset between placing one 
stone and the next?  Or were the 5 placed stones just the 5 highest outputs 
taken from a single evaluation of the framework?

	Presumably placed stones appeared as 1's or -1's in the input just like 
the setup ones?  Since the latter can be used for scoring, but the former 
not, how did the networks distinguish between them?  (obviously this would 
only matter if the stones were placed one at a time)

	If a stone could be placed touching two of the originals, how did that score?

	I assume that the mapping of board-locations to inputs is entirely 
anonymous.  e.g. there's nothing in the system that provides any hint that 
(1,2) is close to (2,2) or that (1,2) and (2,2) have the same relationship 
as (2,4) and (3,4)...  Presumably with the framework<->module mapping, you 
hope to see reuse of the same module on different areas of the board.  If I 
am right in my assumption just here, then this would require multiple 
coordinated mutations (to map the inputs to another area of the same 
shape).  Isn't that putting rather a low-probability obstacle in the 
way?  Did you do any analysis to reveal reuse where the same module is 
mapped in the same way to different locations?  e.g. Fixed width font 
required, numbers represent the position of a network's inputs on the board:

-1---
243--
-5---
-----
-----

translated:

-----
--1--
-243-
--5--
-----

and/or rotated:

-2---
541--
-3---
-----
-----

	Did you consider letting the framework specify that one network's input be 
taken from another's outputs?  I can't remember now whether you were 
permitting recurrence in the networks.  Even if you were, you would 
probably want to forbid it _between_ networks, but feeding one networks 
output into another would allow one network to encapsulate a low-level 
concept (like "stone is isolated") and be used by a higher-level 
network.  Actually, this is probably more advanced than required by your game.

	Ian B
